docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 3 DISMISSAL OF PROCEEDINGS ETC FOR LACK OF PROGRESS [rr 12.7–12.10]

heading.title: PART 12 DISCONTINUANCE, WITHDRAWAL, DISMISSAL AND SETTING ASIDE OF ORIGINATING PROCESS [rr 12.1–12.11]
DIVISION 3 DISMISSAL OF PROCEEDINGS ETC FOR LACK OF PROGRESS [rr 12.7–12.10]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 12 DISCONTINUANCE, WITHDRAWAL, DISMISSAL AND SETTING ASIDE OF ORIGINATING PROCESS [rr 12.1–12.11]
DIVISION 3 DISMISSAL OF PROCEEDINGS ETC FOR LACK OF PROGRESS [rr 12.7–12.10]

leg:heading.title: DISMISSAL OF PROCEEDINGS ETC FOR LACK OF PROGRESS [rr 12.7–12.10]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 12.7] r 12.7 Dismissal of proceedings etc for want of due despatch (cf SCR Part 5, rule 12, Part 32A, rules 1 and 2; DCR Part 18, rules 3 and 9; LCR Part 17, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Dismissal of proceedings etc for want of due despatch (cf SCR Part 5, rule 12, Part 32A, rules 1 and 2; DCR Part 18, rules 3 and 9; LCR Part 17, rule 4)

p.text: If a plaintiff does not prosecute the proceedings with due despatch, the court may order that the proceedings be dismissed or make such other order as the court thinks fit.
If the defendant does not conduct the defence with due despatch, the court may strike out the defence, either in whole or in part, or make such other order as the court thinks fit.
See rule 42.20 as to the effect of dismissal with respect to costs.
[r 12.7 am Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[25], effective 15 August 2005]

level.toc-caption: [12.7.5] Dismissal for want of due progress

p.text: Legislation cited in [12.7.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56, s 58, s 59.

heading.title: Dismissal for want of due progress

p.text: The power to dismiss an action (or strike out a defence) for want of prosecution is not confined by rigid guidelines: Stollznow v Calvert [1980] 2 NSWLR 749 ; Witten v Lombard Australia Ltd [1968] 2 NSWR 529; (1968) 88 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 405 at 411 ; Micallef v ICI Australia Operations Pty Ltd [2001] NSWCA 274; BC200104963 . Although delay is the threshold circumstance that potentially enlivens the power, it is a relative concept and the significance of any delay must depend on the particular circumstances of the case involved: Bishopsgate Insurance Australia Ltd (in liq) v Deloitte Haskins & Sells [1999] 3 VR 863 ; Masel v Transport Industries Insurance Co Ltd [1995] 2 VR 328 . In an attempt to emphasise the required process of evaluation, some English authorities have held that the power to dismiss an action for want of prosecution should be exercised only where the plaintiff's default has been intentional and contumelious or where there has been inordinate and inexcusable delay giving rise either to a substantial risk that a fair trial would not be possible or to a risk of serious prejudice to the defendant: Birkett v James [1978] AC 297 at 318; [1977] 2 All ER 801; [1977] 3 WLR 38 . But this prescription has been rejected as unduly restricting the true scope of the power to strike out for want of prosecution: Stollznow v Calvert [1980] 2 NSWLR 749 ; Micallef v ICI Australia Operations Pty Ltd [2001] NSWCA 274; BC200104963 (multiple failures to comply with directions); and, in any event, may require modification in the light of the “overriding purpose” rule in CPA s 56 and the obligation imposed by CPA s 59 to avoid delay: see Securum Finance Ltd v Ashton [2001] Ch 291; [2000] 3 WLR 1400 ; State of New South Wales v Plaintiff A [2012] NSWCA 248; BC201206211 at [17] .

The essential criterion for the exercise of the power is whether or not, in all the circumstances, justice requires that the proceedings should be dismissed or the defence struck out. That criterion commonly involves striking a balance between the plaintiff and the defendant: Witten v Lombard Australia Ltd [1968] 2 NSWR 529; (1968) 88 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 405 at 411 ; Southern Cross Exploration NL v Fire & All Risks Insurance Co Ltd (1986) 4 NSWLR 491 ; McKenna v McKenna [1984] VR 665 ; Stollznow v Calvert [1980] 2 NSWLR 749 ; Hartigan v International Krishna Consciousness Inc [1999] NSWSC 57; BC9900282 ; although more general considerations concerning the efficiency of the court's proceedings are also relevant considerations: Micallef v ICI Australia Operations Pty Ltd [2001] NSWCA 274; BC200104963 at [63]–[64] and see also CPA s 58 .

The balancing exercise involved permits consideration of a wide range of factors, many of which were helpfully detailed in Hoser v Hartcher [1999] NSWSC 527; BC9902856 at [19] and [30] and approved in Gill v Eatts (1999) Aust Torts Reports 81-529; [1999] NSWSC 1056; BC9906939 . Those factors can be summarised as follows:

heading.title: Prejudice to the party complaining about the lack of progress

p.text: Under this heading the court will look at present, past and future prejudice: Casauria v De Kever (VSC, Hayne J, No 508/198821, November 1994, unreported, BC9405828) (any future trial would occur 12 years after the relevant events). The court should consider:
the length of the delay, and the nature of any procedural non-compliance, in the conduct of the proceedings;
(particularly in the case of delay by a plaintiff) the delay between the cause of action, any notice of intended action, and the commencement of the action;
any relevant change in circumstances, particularly changes in relation to insurance, since the cause of action accrued;
the prior attitude and conduct of the other party, such as:
waiver of or acquiescence in, the delay;
being themselves the cause of unnecessary delay; or

allowing an opposing party to incur further costs in the reasonable belief that no point would be taken about the delay: Queensland Trustees Ltd v Drysdale Hendy & Co (a firm) [1992] 2 Qd R 625 ; Ulowski v Miller [1968] SASR 277 ; St Martin's Centre Pty Ltd v Civil & Civic Pty Ltd (1989) 10 BCL 113 ; Roebuck v Mungovin [1994] 2 AC 224; [1994] 1 All ER 568; [1994] 2 WLR 290 (action by a defendant that induces a plaintiff to incur further expense in prosecuting the proceedings does not preclude an application to strike out for want of prosecution and is only one of the discretionary factors to be taken into account).

Anxiety resulting from the existence of the unresolved litigation is not itself a sufficient prejudice to justify striking out proceedings for want of prosecution by a plaintiff: Department of Transport v Chris Smaller (Transport) Ltd [1989] AC 1197; [1989] 1 All ER 897; [1989] 2 WLR 578 ; Lewandowski v Lovell (1994) 11 WAR 124; BC9401588 .

heading.title: Prejudice to the party responsible for the lack of progress

p.text: In considering prejudice to the party responsible for the impugned delay the court will have regard to:

the nature and extent of, as well as the party’s explanations for, any delay: eg Petronaitis v Rowles [2012] NSWCA 236; BC201205729 (inadequate explanation for failure to attend on multiple occasions);

the party’s degree of personal fault for the delay: Building Insurers’ Guarantee Corporation v Touma [2010] NSWSC 4; BC201000056 (defendant in default of discovery frequent changes of legal representation and spurious adjournment applications — defence struck out);

the degree to which the party has kept the other parties informed of the cause of the delay (noting that the obligations of a plaintiff to have the action brought on promptly are greater than those of a defendant): Calvert v Stollznow (NSWSC, Cross J, CL 8416/70, 1 April 1980, unreported); on appeal Stoll-znow v Calvert [1980] 2 NSWLR 749 at 751 ; Ulowski v Miller [1968] SASR 277 .

Unreasonable delay by a plaintiff after an unsuccessful application to dismiss for want of prosecution could found another application. On that further application, the court could take account of the earlier delay: Allen v Sir Alfred McAlpine & Sons Ltd [1968] 2 QB 229; [1968] 1 All ER 543; [1968] 2 WLR 366 ; Queensland Trustees Ltd v Drysdale Hendy & Co (a firm), above.

Where the relevant limitation period has not expired, it will not ordinarily be a proper exercise of the discretion to grant the application and either stay or dismiss the proceedings — at least unless there has been intentional delay or deliberate disobedience to an order of the court: Birkett v James [1978] AC 297 at 321; [1977] 2 All ER 801 ; Krakauer v Katz [1954] 1 All ER 244; [1954] 1 WLR 278 . Striking out for want of prosecution when a fair trial remains possible and the defendant is not otherwise prejudiced would not be an appropriate sanction, even for inordinate delay, in the conduct of litigation: Department of Transport v Chris Smaller (Transport) Ltd [1989] 1 AC 1197; [1989] 1 All ER 897 . On the other hand, there is no doubt that delay may seriously jeopardise the prospect of a fair and proper determination of the issues. Where delay of that kind has occurred further prosecution of the proceedings may constitute an abuse of process and enliven the court’s power of dismissal or stay — irrespective of either the non-expiry of a relevant statutory limitation period or the absence of any personal misconduct by the moving party: Batistatos v RTA of NSW (2006) 227 ALR 425; [2006] HCA 27; BC200604226 at [60] –[71]; see further [14.28.5] .

Despite some controversy in the decided cases (see, for example, the cases summarised in Stollznow v Calvert [1980] 2 NSWLR 749 ), and despite also the relevance of enquiring as to the extent to which the plaintiff is personally responsible for any delay which may have occurred (Sophron v Nominal Defendant (1957) 96 CLR 469; 31 ALJR 395; BC5700210 ), it now appears settled that in dealing with an application to stay or dismiss proceedings for want of prosecution it is appropriate to consider the extent to which the plaintiff may have an alternative remedy against his solicitor: Stollznow v Calvert [1980] 2 NSWLR 749 ; Birkett v James [1978] AC 297; [1977] 2 All ER 801 ; McKenna v McKenna [1984] VR 665 ; Repco Corp Ltd v Scardamaglia (1995) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-330; Morrison v Judd (NSWCA, Kirby P, Meagher, Powell JJA, 405041/95, 10 October 1995, unreported, BC9507158)). However, while the existence of such a potential claim is a relevant consideration, it is one that will usually carry little weight: Morrison v Judd, above.

The principles governing an application to dismiss for want of prosecution assume the plaintiff satisfies the court that there is a genuine intention to bring the proceedings to hearing. If it can be shown that the plaintiff has no such intention, the proceedings are liable to be struck out as an abuse of process — irrespective of whether there is any evidence of delay or consequential prejudice to the defendant: Grovit v Doctor [1997] 2 All ER 417; [1997] 1 WLR 640 .

level.toc-caption: [12.7.25] Desirability of warning of dismissal application

heading.title: Desirability of warning of dismissal application

p.text: A party that intends to apply for an order for dismissal for want of prosecution is well advised to give an appropriate warning of their intention to do so. If the warned party nevertheless fails to proceed in a timely fashion, the prospect of succeeding on the dismissal application may be enhanced. Conversely, the absence of a timely warning may itself provide a basis for resisting the dismissal application: Lancord Pty Ltd v Sibervale Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 1117; BC200608502 (order refused — no prewarning given — delay partly explained and not inordinate or inexcusable); Kapoor v State Transit Authority of NSW [2010] NSWCA 143; BC201004347 (ex parte oral dismissal application made without prior notice — denial of procedural fairness — set aside on appeal).

level.toc-caption: [12.7.30] Dismissal of cross-claim for want of prosecution

heading.title: Dismissal of cross-claim for want of prosecution

p.text: The court can dismiss a cross-claim for want of prosecution. However, if the proceedings on the plaintiff's claim have not been disposed of, a plaintiff who seeks to dismiss the cross-claim will ordinarily also have to consent to the dismissal of its own claim: Barrington Black Austin & Co v Dickson (UKCA, 13 May 1997, unreported).
Legislation cited in [12.7.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.16(1).

An application under r 36.16(1) of the UCPR to set aside the dismissal of the proceedings will rarely succeed if the plaintiff has not remedied the default that occasioned the dismissal: National Parks and Wildlife Service v Pierson (2002) 55 NSWLR 315; [2002] NSWCA 273; BC200204666 at [19] . Any subsequent application to set aside the dismissal will constitute an abuse of process, unless there has been a relevant change of circumstances: National Parks and Wildlife Service v Pierson , above, at [18]; and will, in any event, face the difficulty of persuading the court to entertain multiple interlocutory applications for the same relief: Nominal Defendant v Manning (2000) 50 NSWLR 139; 31 MVR 524; [2000] NSWCA 80; BC200005011 ; Fletcher v Besser [2010] NSWCA 30; BC201001212 at [17]; National Parks and Wildlife Service v Pierson , above, at [18] and [19].

level.toc-caption: [12.7.40] Effect of dismissal for want of prosecution

p.text: Legislation cited in [12.7.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 91.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 12.10(b).

heading.title: Effect of dismissal for want of prosecution

p.text: The dismissal of an action for want of prosecution is no bar to the commencement of further proceedings: Pople v Evans [1969] 2 Ch 255; [1968] 2 All ER 743 at 751–2 ; Re Orrell Colliery & Fire Bricks Co (1879) 12 Ch D 681 ; G S Bower and A K Turner, The Doctrine of Res Judicata, 2nd ed, Sweet & Maxwell, 1969 at pp 36–7. This principle is also made explicit by the terms of CPA s 91 and UCPR r 12.10(b) .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 12.8] r 12.8 Additional grounds for dismissal of proceedings by Supreme Court or Land and Environment Court (cf SCR Part 32A, rules 1 and 2)

leg:heading.title: Additional grounds for dismissal of proceedings by Supreme Court or Land and Environment Court (cf SCR Part 32A, rules 1 and 2)

p.text: This rule applies to proceedings in the Supreme Court or the Land and Environment Court.
[subr (1) am Amendment 20 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[3], effective 28 January 2008]

The court may, of its own motion, make an order dismissing the proceedings if it appears from the court’s records that, for over 5 months, no party to the proceedings has taken any step in the proceedings.
[subr (2) am Amendment 20 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[4], effective 28 January 2008]
Such an order may not be made:
if the proceedings, or any part of the proceedings, are listed for a future date, or
if there are any notices of motion or other applications in the proceedings that are yet to be determined, or
if a party satisfies the court that such an order should not be made.
[subr (3) am Amendment 20 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[4], effective 28 January 2008]

Before such an order is made, notice of the proposed order is to be given to the plaintiff and to each other active party, being a notice that gives each of them a reasonable opportunity to be heard in relation to the proposal.
Such a notice is to be sent by post, addressed to the person to whom it is directed:
at the person’s address for service, or
if the person has no address for service, at the person’s last known address,
in an envelope marked with the court’s return address.
[subr (5) am Amendment 20 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[4], effective 28 January 2008]

A notice, posted as referred to in subrule (5), is taken to have been received by the person to whom it was addressed even if it is returned to the court as having not been delivered to the addressee.
[subr (6) am Amendment 20 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[4], effective 28 January 2008]
[r 12.8 subst Amendment 3 of 2005 r 2and Sch 1[12], effective 30 September 2005]

level.toc-caption: [12.8.5] Inactivity as a ground for dismissal

p.text: Legislation cited in [12.8.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56(3).

heading.title: Inactivity as a ground for dismissal

p.text: Inactivity will normally only justify dismissal of proceedings under the present rule where the court is satisfied the moving party does not intend to prosecute the proceedings to final hearing and do so in a manner complying with their obligations under CPA s 56(3) : see further [s 59.10] and [12.9.5] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 12.9] r 12.9 Additional grounds for dismissal of proceedings by District Court or Local Court

leg:heading.title: Additional grounds for dismissal of proceedings by District Court or Local Court

p.text: This rule applies to proceedings in the District Court or the Local Court that have been commenced by statement of claim or in which a statement of claim has been filed.
[subr (1) am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[1], effective 6 July 2009]
The court may, of its own motion, make an order dismissing the proceedings if:
a defence or cross-claim is not filed, or
an application for default judgment is not filed, or
the proceedings are not otherwise disposed of,
within 9 months after the statement of claim is filed.
[subr (2) am Gaz 87 of 6 July 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[1], effective 6 July 2007]
Such an order may be made without notice to the plaintiff or any other party.
Such an order may not be made if there are any notices of motion or other applications in the proceedings that are yet to be determined.
Legislation cited in [12.9.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56, s 56(1), s 56(3), s 91.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.16(2)(b).

Although the present rule confers a power to dismiss proceedings without notice to the parties, general princple suggests that the occasions for its exercise will be exceptional. First of all, general principle suggests the potential injustice, and in the light of the overriding purpose stated in CPA s 56(1) the consequential undesirability, of making orders without notice to the parties. Second, UCPR r 36.16(2)(b) permits any order made in the absence of a party to be set aside. If the affected parties made a successful application under that rule, the dismissal order would simply result in increasing the costs of the proceedings. Third, CPA s 91 specifically provides that dismissal of proceedings generally does not preclude the commencement of new proceedings claiming the same relief. For all of these reasons, and the general considerations discussed in [12.7.5] and [12.7.10] , compliance with the overriding purpose obligation in CPA s 56 would generally make it inappropriate to dismiss proceedings, on the ground of mere delay, unless the Court was satisfied the moving party did not intend to prosecute the proceedings to final hearing and do so in a manner that complied with their obligations under CPA s 56(3) .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 12.10] r 12.10 Stay of further proceedings to secure costs of proceedings dismissed (cf SCR Part 40, rule 8(2); DCR Part 18, rule 8; LCR Part 17, rule 9)

leg:heading.title: Stay of further proceedings to secure costs of proceedings dismissed (cf SCR Part 40, rule 8(2); DCR Part 18, rule 8; LCR Part 17, rule 9)

p.text: If:
as a consequence of the dismissal of proceedings, a party is liable to pay the costs of another party in relation to those proceedings, and

before payment of the costs, the party commences further proceedings against that other party on the same or substantially the same cause of action, or for the same or substantially the same relief, as that on or for which the former proceedings were commenced,
the court may stay the further proceedings until those costs are paid and make such consequential orders as it thinks fit.
See also section 67 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 as to the terms on which a stay may be granted, and rule 42.20 as to costs payable in relation to proceedings that are dismissed.
Legislation cited in [12.10.2] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 61(3), s 91(1), s 91(2).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 12.7–12.9.

Dismissal of proceedings, either for want of despatch or on the additional grounds set out in the present rule, does not necessarily preclude the subsequent commencement of new proceedings: see CPA s 91(1) and [12.7.40] . The possible commencement of new proceedings assumes that the dismissal does not involve any determination of the merits of the claim — because both CPA s 91(2) and the ordinary principles of res judicata (see [14.28.15] ) preclude re-litigation of proceedings after a hearing on the merits: Newmont Pty Ltd v Laverton Nickel NL (No 2) [1981] 1 NSWLR 221 as noted at (1978) 3 ACLR 945. Even where there has been no determination on the merits, there is a potential distinction between, on the one hand, cases where the earlier proceedings have been dismissed for want of despatch (see UCPR rr 12.7–12.9 ) or failure to comply with the rules and, on the other hand, cases where proceedings have been dismissed (for example in the exercise of the power conferred by CPA s 61(3) ) for failure to comply with a peremptory order of the court: Andrew v Baradom Holdings Pty Ltd (in liq) (1995) 36 NSWLR 700; 17 ACSR 231; BC9504567 ; Bailey v Bailey [1983] 3 All ER 495 . In the latter situation, if the plaintiff commences new proceedings and does not provide any proper explanation for the failure to comply with the orders made in the earlier proceedings, an application may properly be made to strike out the second proceedings as an abuse of process: Janov v Morris [1981] 3 All ER 780; [1981] 1 WLR 1389 ; Re Jokai Tea Holdings Ltd [1992] 1 WLR 1196 ; Grand Metropolitan Nominee (No 2) Co Ltd v Evans [1993] 1 All ER 642; [1992] 1 WLR 1191 ; Deangrove Pty Ltd v Commonwealth Bank of Australia (2001) 108 FCR 77; 37 ACSR 465 (legal advice resulting in non-compliance with self executing order — no abuse of process).

Where a plaintiff has discontinued proceedings or has failed in an action and seeks to bring a second action based on the same facts against the same defendant, the general rule is that the court will stay proceedings in the second action unless the costs of the first action are paid. The reason behind the rule is that prima facie unless those costs are paid, the second action is vexatious and oppressive. The plaintiff must therefore show some special circumstance which will justify the second action being allowed to proceed before the costs of the first action are paid: see generally Re Payne (1883) 23 Ch D 288 ; Martin v Beauchamp (1883) 25 Ch D 12 ; McCabe v Bank of Ireland (1889) 14 App Cas 413 . The right to a stay is not absolute, but is an exercise of the court's discretion on the basis that it would be unjust and oppressive to permit the second action to continue. Factors to be taken into account are:
the merits of the case; and
the likelihood of the defendant having to pay additional party and party costs if the second action were allowed to proceed.

Where a plaintiff was granted legal aid pursuant to which the defendant had the right to have his or her taxed costs paid out of the suitor's fund if he or she were successful, and would therefore incur no additional party and party costs by reason of the failure in the second action of an inpecunious plaintiff, the second action is allowed to proceed: Hutchinson v Nominal Defendant [1972] 1 NSWLR 443 . However, in the peculiar circumstances of Dunbee Ltd v Gilman & Co (Aust) Pty Ltd [1969] 1 NSWR 406; (1968) 89 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 259 , a second action was stayed in the exercise of the court's discretion despite the fact that the appellant defendant had sought, and the respondent plaintiff had consented to give, security for costs of the second action, the plaintiff being a foreign company who would almost certainly have been ordered to give security in any event because of that fact.
